author: Liz Farquhar
title: Hunter Valley Drayton South mine expansion rejected again - ABC News (Australian Broadcasting Corporation)
text:
Map: Singleton 2330 
A major Hunter Valley mine expansion has been rejected for the fourth time, amid concerns it poses too many risks to the environment. 
Mining giant Anglo American had proposed its Drayton South project several years ago, but it was rejected three times, ahead of its latest assessment. 
The independent Planning Assessment Commission (PAC) today said there were too many risks in relation to noise, air quality and other impacts. 
Hunter Valley thoroughbred studs said they would be forced to leave the area if the controversial mine expansion was approved. 
President of the Singleton Business Chamber Ruth Rogers said the rejection of the Drayton South project was a massive blow. 
"Well I'm totally disappointed," she said. 
"They actually gave us false hope saying that we had another chance. 
"Obviously the PAC have disagreed with the community. 
"I'm very disappointed because it is not just about the workers it's also about the economy of Singleton, Muswellbrook and Scone and all the outlying areas as well." 
Ms Rogers said it was nonsense to say coal mining and horse breeding industries could not continue to co-exist. 
"We've lived in coexistence in the past since 1981and I don't understand why all of a sudden that we can't live in coexistence now," she said. 
"So it is disappointing not just for the workers but for their families and also for all the ongoing industries that are attached to it as well." 
Ms Rogers said the ongoing impasse relating to the Drayton South project had caused massive divisions in the community. 
"It's ripped apart the community and it is the ongoing effect financially for people," Ms Rogers said. 
"It is the small businesses, the large businesses but it is also the mental [effects] which I call the invincible wound of the members who have now lost all hope. 
"They have got to go and find jobs, it is going to be a mental strain on them, their families and I just hope that these other mines can be picked up so that they can be re-employed."
